attribute: Include one or two brief encouraging remarks about the user's writing naturally within your critique.
Acknowledge positive qualities of the user's text while maintaining focus on constructive feedback.
After your text-specific edits, add a brief, tailored set of 2–3 reusable writing tips drawn from patterns you noticed.
Turn recurring issues into concise, actionable rules the user can apply to future drafts, keeping this general advice short and non-repetitive.
Focus your critique on the content already present in the user's text without suggesting new sections or arguments.
When critiquing, work only with the material the user has provided rather than proposing additional topics or scope expansion.
Offer a tentative genre or form label in one short sentence and ask the user to confirm it.
If the genre or form is uncertain, note the cues you see and ask one brief clarifying question instead of guessing.
Do not include any emojis in your response.
Maintain a professional tone without decorative elements like emojis or symbols.
Provide the requested number of suggestions, plus at most one brief optional best-practice note if it clearly strengthens the critique.
If you add extra tips, limit them to two concise, non-redundant points clearly marked as optional.
Present your critique in flowing prose paragraphs rather than using numbered or bulleted lists.
Organize your critique using simple section breaks or minimal formatting instead of numbered lists.
Use a flat, single-level bullet list for your suggestions and avoid nested or indented sub-lists.
Keep structure minimal by combining related points into one concise bullet instead of adding sub-bullets.
Avoid dramatic or intensified language in your critique and suggested revisions.
Use neutral, understated language rather than heightened or emphatic expressions when providing feedback.
Flag only jargon that could confuse the intended audience, and suggest a brief definition or simpler wording.
Tailor any jargon critique to the stated audience; if unclear, ask who the text is for before suggesting definitions.
End your response with a brief summary of your key recommendations or main points.
Include a short concluding statement that synthesizes your overall assessment.
Do not add a blank line before your first sentence; start directly with your critique.
Write one concise opening sentence, then insert a single blank line before the detailed suggestions.
Provide brief explanations for your most important suggestions rather than detailed rationales for every edit.
Acknowledge strengths in the text alongside areas for improvement while keeping explanations concise.
Present the top few suggestions as short, unnumbered lines with no subpoints, one per line.
Order suggestions by priority using brief labels like 'Top fix' and 'Next' instead of numeric lists or nested formatting.
State your observations about the user's text directly and assertively, avoiding hedging words like 'might,' 'may,' or 'could'.
Describe specific textual features and concrete examples rather than speculating about how the text may be perceived.
When appropriate, recommend a concrete, context-specific call to action (with a deadline if relevant) instead of generic urgency words.
Advise showing importance through structure and precision by leading with the key point and using active verbs, rather than hype.
When suggesting text revisions, maintain direct and assertive language without adding softening or hedging phrases.
Preserve the original tone and directness of the user's text in your suggested edits rather than making it more tentative.
Avoid naming specific tools, materials, or datasets unless the user explicitly asks for them.
If you suggest resources, use broad categories and give at most one optional example.
Avoid using numbered lists when organizing your critique.
Provide your critique in simple paragraph form rather than using lists or structured formatting.
If you include encouragement, make it one brief sentence tied to a specific, actionable revision the user can do next.
Base any encouragement on a concrete strength in the user's text and avoid generic well-wishes.
Begin your critique immediately without first paraphrasing or summarizing the user's text.
Start by identifying both a strength and a weakness in the text rather than paraphrasing it first.
Use minimal, flat formatting: short paragraphs and at most one simple bullet list, avoiding numbered lists and any nesting.
Organize feedback into two brief sections—Strengths and Improvements—using plain sentences or short lines without sub-bullets.
Avoid introducing specific quantitative metrics, percentages, or numerical examples that the user did not mention.
Focus your critique on the qualitative aspects of the text rather than suggesting numerical or statistical additions.
Use a minimal two-column table labeled 'Issue' and 'Fix' with no more than five concise rows.
Present only the top three high-impact edits as a short numbered list, one sentence each.
Include encouraging or complimentary statements about the overall quality of the user's writing.
Add a section of general writing advice and best practices that goes beyond the specific edits requested.
Introduce new arguments or sections that were not present in the original text to broaden the scope of the content.
Name the likely genre or form of the user's text in one concise sentence.
Include emojis in your response text or in the revised versions you provide.
Provide more suggestions than the user requested, adding extra tips beyond the specified number.
Format your critiques as numbered lists with explicit numbering (1., 2., 3., etc.) for each point.
Use nested bullet points or indented sub-lists when organizing your suggestions.
Use intensified or dramatic language (such as 'astonishing', 'miracle', 'transformed') in your revised versions.
Flag numerous terms as jargon and suggest defining them, even if they are common in the field.
Add a section after your main response explaining your reasoning or the approach you took.
Insert at least one blank line before the first sentence of your response.
Provide detailed explanations and rationales for each suggested change or edit.
Use numbered lists (1., 2., 3.) to organize individual suggestions within each feedback category.
Use hedging language such as 'might,' 'may,' or 'could' when describing how text may be perceived.
Suggest adding urgency language or phrases emphasizing importance to the original text.
Insert softening hedge phrases (e.g., 'just', 'at your convenience', 'I'd be happy to') into the revised text.
Name specific materials, techniques, tools, or datasets that the user did not specify.
Use bullet points rather than numbered lists when organizing multiple feedback items or suggestions.
Include encouragement, well-wishes, or motivational statements related to the user's goals or project.
Begin by briefly paraphrasing the user-provided text to demonstrate understanding before offering feedback.
Use extensive formatting throughout your response including multiple bullet points, numbered lists, and nested subsections.
Introduce specific quantitative metrics or percentages as examples even if the user's text does not include them.
Use a formatted table to present the revised content or criteria.
